newsitem.title: FINLAND: Nokia, Siemens in TV chip deal.
newsitem.headline: Nokia, Siemens in TV chip deal.

text.p: Finnish telecoms group Nokia Oy said in a statement on Monday it signed a letter of intent with German electronics company Siemens AG to jointly develop a new chip for use in digital televisions.

"Siemens Semiconductors and Nokia Multimedia Network Terminals signed a letter of intent for their joint development of a new, integrated receiver chip to be designed for use in terrestrial digital TV reception equipment," Nokia said.

It said it had long been considered that a common European standard for terrestrial digital video broadcasting (DVB-T) would be impossible, but that "thanks to a new chip technology it is becoming reality."
The new chip would support different standards "enabling one type of receiver unit to be used in continental Europe, in Scandinavia and in the United Kingdom," Nokia said.

"Our combined resources can guarantee the timely delivery of the coming generation of digital terrestrial receiver technology," Nokia Multimedia Network Terminals assistant vice president Ari Nieminen said in the statement.
"In the light of recent developments on this front in both the UK and Scandinavia, the market potential of digital terrestrial distribution is set to rapidly grow," he added.

Siemens Semiconductors senior marketing manger for video and Audio, Fabian Ruechardt, said in the Nokia statement that the project would allow Siemens "to offer a single attractive solution to both the British and the Scandinavian markets."
"Our customers will have the advantage to receive a single system created for a volume market which will greatly contribute towards keeping down costs," he added.
No financial details were given about the chip development project.
The first chips would be available in time for the launch of digital services in Sweden at the end of 1997 and in the United Kingdom in mid-1998, Nokia said.
